summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California today entered a final judgment against Dignity Health, Inc., a California-based health care conglomerate, and its co-defendant, Adedipe Health, LLC, in a civil injunctive action.  The court also entered a temporary restraining order against the defendants from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on April 1, 2013 and unsealed on June 11, 2014, Dignity and Adejay Health agreed to settle the case by consenting to the entry of judgments that permanently enjoin them from future violations of the federal securities laws. The judgment also permanently enjoins them from violating Section 17(a)(1) and (3) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act"), and orders them to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties in amounts to be determined by the court at a later date.  In addition, the court granted the defendants' motion for summary judgment on June 13, 2016, and ordered the defendants to pay a civil penalty of $1,000. The settlement is subject to court approval. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by John Rymas of the Chicago Regional Office. The litigation will be led by Jeffrey A. Herman. The case is being supervised by C.J. Kerstetter, Chief of the Market Abuse Unit. The examination that led to the investigation was conducted by Eric R. Werner and supervised by Kelly L. Gibson of the Division of Enforcement's Asset Management Unit.Â  The case was supervised by Jennifer C. Barry. Â The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the California Department of Insurance, and the Arizona Secretary of State's Office in this matter.
